The right to receive a copy, on request, of the criteria upon which the facility makes its decision to admit or discharge a consumer from the facility. Such criteria must not, for emergency admissions or involuntary court-ordered admissions, be based on the availability of insurance coverage or any other financial considerations. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½improper conductï¿½ means a violation of the rules, policies or procedures of the facility.

section.heading: Rights concerning involuntary commitment.

content.p: Each consumer admitted for evaluation, treatment or training to a facility has the following rights concerning involuntary commitment to the facility, a list of which must be prominently posted in all facilities providing those services and must be otherwise brought to the attention of the consumer by such additional means as prescribed by regulation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

To request and receive a second evaluation by a psychiatrist or psychologist who does not have a contractual relationship with or financial interest in the facility. The evaluation must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Include, without limitation, a recommendation of whether the consumer should be involuntarily committed to the facility; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Be paid for by the consumer if the insurance carrier of the consumer refuses to pay for the evaluation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To receive a copy of the procedure of the facility regarding involuntary commitment and treatment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To receive a list of the consumerï¿½s rights concerning involuntary commitment or treatment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the results of an evaluation conducted by a psychiatrist or psychologist pursuant to subsection 1 conflict in any manner with the results of an evaluation conducted by the facility, the facility may request and receive a third evaluation of the consumer to resolve the conflicting portions of the previous evaluations.

section.heading: Personal rights.

content.p: To wear the consumerï¿½s own clothing, to keep and use his or her own personal possessions, including toilet articles, unless those articles may be used to endanger the consumerï¿½s life or othersï¿½ lives, and to keep and be allowed to spend a reasonable sum of the consumerï¿½s own money for expenses and small purchases. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To have access to individual space for storage for his or her private use. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To see visitors each day. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To have reasonable access to telephones, both to make and receive confidential calls. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To have ready access to materials for writing letters, including stamps, and to mail and receive unopened correspondence, but: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the purposes of this subsection, packages are not considered as correspondence; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Correspondence identified as containing a check payable to a consumer may be subject to control and safekeeping by the administrative officer of that facility or the administrative officerï¿½s designee, so long as the consumerï¿½s record of treatment documents the action. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To have reasonable access to an interpreter if the consumer does not speak English or is hearing impaired. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

To designate a person who must be kept informed by the facility of the consumerï¿½s medical and mental condition, if the consumer signs a release allowing the facility to provide such information to the person. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided inNRS 439.597, to have access to the consumerï¿½s medical records denied to any person other than: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who obtains a waiver by the consumer of his or her right to keep the medical records confidential; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who obtains a court order authorizing the access. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Other personal rights as specified by regulation of the Commission.

section.heading: Rights concerning care, treatment and training.

content.p: To medical, psychosocial and rehabilitative care, treatment and training including prompt and appropriate medical treatment and care for physical and mental ailments and for the prevention of any illness or disability. All of that care, treatment and training must be consistent with standards of practice of the respective professions in the community and is subject to the following conditions: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Before instituting a plan of care, treatment or training or carrying out any necessary surgical procedure, express and informed consent must be obtained in writing from: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The consumer if he or she is 18 years of age or over or legally emancipated and has the capacity to give that consent, and from the consumerï¿½s legal guardian, if any; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The parent or guardian of a consumer under 18 years of age and not legally emancipated; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An informed consent requires that the person whose consent is sought be adequately informed as to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The reasonable risks, benefits and purposes of the procedure; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Alternative procedures available; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The consent of a consumer as provided in paragraph

Even in the absence of express and informed consent, a licensed and qualified physician may render emergency medical care or treatment to any consumer who has been injured in an accident or motor vehicle crash or who is suffering from an acute illness, disease or condition, if within a reasonable degree of medical certainty, delay in the initiation of emergency medical care or treatment would endanger the health of the consumer and if the treatment is immediately entered into the consumerï¿½s record of treatment, subject to the provisions of paragraph
; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the proposed emergency medical care or treatment is deemed by the chief medical officer of the facility to be unusual, experimental or generally occurring infrequently in routine medical practice, the chief medical officer shall request consultation from other physicians or practitioners of healing arts who have knowledge of the proposed care or treatment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To be free from abuse, neglect and aversive intervention. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

To consent to the consumerï¿½s transfer from one facility to another, except that the Administrator of the Division of Public and Behavioral Health of the Department or the Administratorï¿½s designee, or the Administrator of the Division of Child and Family Services of the Department or the Administratorï¿½s designee, may order a transfer to be made whenever conditions concerning care, treatment or training warrant it. If the consumer in any manner objects to the transfer, the person ordering it must enter the objection and a written justification of the transfer in the consumerï¿½s record of treatment and immediately forward a notice of the objection to the Administrator who ordered the transfer, and the Commission shall review the transfer pursuant to subsection 3 ofNRS 433.534. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Other rights concerning care, treatment and training as may be specified by regulation of the Commission.

section.heading: Individualized plan of services for consumer.

content.p: An individualized written plan of mental health services must be developed for each consumer of each facility. The plan must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Provide for the least restrictive treatment procedure that may reasonably be expected to benefit the consumer; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Be developed with the input and participation of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The consumer, to the extent that he or she is able to provide input and participate; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

To the extent that the consumer is unable to provide input and participate, the parent or guardian of the consumer if the consumer is under 18 years of age and is not legally emancipated, or the legal guardian of a consumer who has been adjudicated incapacitated. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The plan must be kept current and must be modified, with the input and participation of the consumer, the parent or guardian of the consumer or the legal guardian of the consumer, as appropriate, when indicated. The plan must be thoroughly reviewed at least once every 3 months. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person in charge of implementing the plan of services must be designated in the plan.

section.heading: Basis for decisions, policies, procedures and practices regarding emergency admissions and involuntary court-ordered admissions.

content.p: Each facility shall make all of its decisions, policies, procedures and practices regarding emergency admissions or involuntary court-ordered admissions based upon clinical efficiency rather than cost containment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not preclude a public facility from making decisions, policies, procedures and practices within the limits of the money made available to the facility.

section.heading: Right to information; inspection and copying of records.

content.p: A consumer or the consumerï¿½s legal guardian must be: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Informed of the consumerï¿½s clinical status and progress at reasonable intervals of no longer than 3 months in a manner appropriate to his or her clinical condition. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Unless a psychiatrist has made a specific entry to the contrary in a consumerï¿½s records, a consumer or the consumerï¿½s legal guardian is entitled to obtain a copy of the consumerï¿½s records at any time upon notice to the administrative officer of the facility and payment of the cost of reproducing the records.

section.heading: Medication: Responsibility of psychiatrist and physician; review of methods for administration and custody.

content.p: The attending psychiatrist or physician shall be responsible for all medication given or administered to a consumer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Each administrative officer shall establish a policy for the review of the administration, storage and handling of medications by nurses and nonprofessional personnel.

section.heading: Labor by consumer: Conditions; compensation.

content.p: A consumer may perform labor which contributes to the operation and maintenance of the facility for which the facility would otherwise employ someone only if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person responsible for the consumerï¿½s treatment agrees to the plan of labor; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The amount of time or effort necessary to perform the labor is not excessive. ï¿½In no event may discharge or privileges be conditioned upon the performance of such labor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A consumer who performs labor which contributes to the operation and maintenance of the facility for which the facility would otherwise employ someone must be adequately compensated and the compensation must be in accordance with applicable state and federal labor laws. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A consumer who performs labor other than that described in subsection 2 must be compensated an adequate amount if an economic benefit to another person or agency results from the consumerï¿½s labor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The administrative officer of the facility may provide for compensation of a resident when the resident performs labor not governed by subsection 2 or 3. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not apply to labor of a personal housekeeping nature or to labor performed as a condition of residence in a small group living arrangement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

One-half of any compensation paid to a consumer pursuant to this section is exempt from collection or retention as payment for services rendered by the Division of Public and Behavioral Health of the Department or its facilities, or by the Division of Child and Family Services of the Department or its facilities. Such an amount is also exempt from levy, execution, attachment, garnishment or any other remedies provided by law for the collection of debts.

section.heading: Rights concerning suspension or violation of rights.

content.p: To receive a list of the consumerï¿½s rights. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To receive a copy of the policy of the facility that sets forth the clinical or medical circumstances under which the consumerï¿½s rights may be suspended or violated. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

To receive a list of the clinically appropriate options available to the consumer or the consumerï¿½s family to remedy an actual or a suspected suspension or violation of his or her rights. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To have all policies of the facility regarding the rights of consumers prominently posted in the facility.

section.heading: Document reflecting receipt of list of rights and explanation of rights.

content.p: Each facility shall, within a reasonable time after a consumer is admitted to the facility for evaluation, treatment or training, ask the consumer to sign a document that reflects that the consumer has received a list of the consumerï¿½s rights and has had those rights explained to him or her.

section.heading: Denial of rights prohibited; exceptions; report; investigation and action by Commission; closure of meeting in certain circumstances.

content.p: The rights of a consumer enumerated in this chapter must not be denied except to protect the consumerï¿½s health and safety or to protect the health and safety of others, or both. Any denial of those rights in any facility must be entered in the consumerï¿½s record of treatment, and notice of the denial must be forwarded to the administrative officer of the facility. Failure to report denial of rights by an employee may be grounds for dismissal. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the administrative officer of a facility receives notice of a denial of rights as provided in subsection 1, the officer shall cause a full report to be prepared which must set forth in detail the factual circumstances surrounding the denial. Except as otherwise provided inNRS 239.0115, such a report is confidential and must not be disclosed. A copy of the report must be sent to the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commission: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
May act on behalf of consumers to obtain remedies for any apparent violations; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Shall otherwise endeavor to safeguard the rights guaranteed by this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Pursuant toNRS 241.030, the Commission may close any portion of a meeting in which it considers the character, alleged misconduct or professional competence of a person in relation to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The denial of the rights of a consumer; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The care and treatment of a consumer. ï¿½The provisions of this subsection do not require a meeting of the Commission to be closed to the public.

section.heading: Retaliation by officer, director or employee of facility prohibited.

content.p: Reported any violation of law; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Provided information regarding a violation of law, ï¿½by the facility or a staff member of the facility.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: ï¿½Administrative officerï¿½ means a person with overall executive and administrative responsibility for a division facility. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Division facilityï¿½ means any unit or subunit operated by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Division of Public and Behavioral Health of the Department for the care, treatment and training of consumers; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Division of Child and Family Services of the Department pursuant tochapter 433Bof NRS.

section.heading: Personal deposit funds for consumers.

content.p: There may be maintained as a trust fund at each division facility a consumersï¿½ personal deposit fund. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Money coming into the possession of the administrative officer of a division facility which belongs to a consumer must be credited in the fund in the name of that consumer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When practicable, individual credits in the fund must not exceed the sum of $300. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any amounts to the credit of a consumer may be used for purchasing personal necessities, for expenses of burial or may be turned over to the consumer upon the consumerï¿½s demand, except that when the consumer is adjudicated incapacitated the guardian of the consumerï¿½s estate has the right to demand and receive the money. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An amount accepted for the benefit of a consumer for a special purpose must be reserved for that purpose regardless of the total amount to the credit of the consumer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 7, the administrative officers shall deposit any money received for the funds of their respective facilities in commercial accounts with one or more banks or credit unions of reputable standing. When deposits in a commercial account exceed $15,000, the administrative officer may deposit the excess in a savings account paying interest in any reputable commercial bank, or in any credit union, savings and loan association or savings bank within this state that is federally insured or insured by a private insurer approved pursuant toNRS 672.755. The savings account must be in the name of the fund. Interest paid on deposits in the savings account may be used for recreational purposes at the division facility. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The administrative officers may maintain at their respective division facilities petty cash of not more than $400 of the money in the consumersï¿½ personal deposit fund to enable consumers to withdraw small sums from their accounts.

section.heading: Disposition of personal property of consumer upon death.

content.p: All documents must be filed by the administrative officer with: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The public administrator of the county from which the consumer was admitted; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the office of public administrator has been abolished pursuant toNRS 253.125, the person employed or contracted with pursuant toNRS 253.125to carry out the duties and responsibilities ofchapter 253of NRS in the county from which the consumer was admitted, ï¿½as applicable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

All other personal property must be sold at a public auction or by sealed bids. The proceeds of the sale must be applied to the decedentï¿½s unpaid balance for costs incurred at the division facility.

section.heading: Disposition of unclaimed personal property of consumer worth more than $100.

content.p: If a person admitted to a division facility is discharged or leaves and the person fails to recover personal property worth more than $100 in the custody of the administrative officer of the facility, the administrative officer shall notify the former consumer or the consumerï¿½s legal representative in writing that personal property remains in the custody of the facility. The property must be held in safekeeping for the consumer for a period of 1 year from the date of discharge. If upon the expiration of the 1-year period no claim has been made upon the administrative officer by the person or the personï¿½s legal representative, another notice must be sent to the person or the personï¿½s legal representative, stating the fact that personal property remains in the custody of the facility, and specifying the manner in which the property will be disposed of if not claimed within 15 business days. After 15 business days, the property may be considered unclaimed property and be disposed of in the manner provided for unclaimed property of deceased persons under the provisions ofNRS 433.541.

section.heading: Disposition of unclaimed personal property of minimal value.

content.p: If, upon the death or release of a person admitted to a division facility, the value of unclaimed personal property in the possession of the administrative officer of the facility is so minimal that it cannot be sold at public auction or by sealed bid and if the property, either in its present condition or in an improved condition, cannot be used by the division facility, the administrative officer may order the personal property destroyed.

section.heading: Notification of death of consumer; burial.

content.p: Upon the death of a consumer, any known relatives or friends of the consumer shall be notified immediately of the fact of death. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Administrator or the Administratorï¿½s designee shall cause a decent burial to be provided for the consumer outside division facility grounds. The Administrator or the designee may enter into a contract with any person or persons, including governmental agencies or other instrumentalities, as the Administrator or the designee deems proper, for a decent burial. Where there are known relatives, and they are financially able, the cost of burial shall be borne by the relatives. Where there are no known relatives, the cost of burial shall be a charge against the State of Nevada, but the cost thereof shall not exceed the amount charged for the burial of indigents in the county in which the burial takes place. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

When a consumer has income from a pension payable through a division facility, and has no guardian, the Division may obligate operating funds for funeral expenses in the amount due under the pension benefits.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used inNRS 433.545to433.551, inclusive, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined inNRS 433.5453to433.548, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: ï¿½Aversive interventionï¿½ defined.

content.p: The use of noxious odors and tastes; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The use of blasts of air; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The use of corporal punishment; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The use of verbal and mental abuse; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The use of electric shock; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Requiring a person to perform exercise under forced conditions if the: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Person is required to perform the exercise because the person exhibited a behavior that is related to his or her disability; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Exercise is harmful to the health of the person because of his or her disability; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any intervention, technique or procedure that deprives a person of the use of one or more of his or her senses, regardless of the length of the deprivation, including, without limitation, the use of sensory screens; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The deprivation of necessities needed to sustain the health of a person, regardless of the length of the deprivation, including, without limitation, the denial or unreasonable delay in the provision of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Food or liquid at a time when it is customarily served; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Medication.

section.heading: ï¿½Chemical restraintï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Chemical restraintï¿½ means the administration of drugs to a person for the specific and exclusive purpose of controlling an acute or episodic behavior that places the person or others at a risk of harm when less restrictive alternative intervention techniques have failed to limit or control the behavior. The term does not include the administration of drugs prescribed by a physician, physician assistant or advanced practice registered nurse as standard treatment for the mental or physical condition of the person.

section.heading: ï¿½Corporal punishmentï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Corporal punishmentï¿½ means the intentional infliction of physical pain, including, without limitation, hitting, pinching or striking.

section.heading: ï¿½Electric shockï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Electric shockï¿½ means the application of electric current to a personï¿½s skin or body. The term does not include electroconvulsive therapy.

section.heading: ï¿½Emergencyï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Emergencyï¿½ means a situation in which immediate intervention is necessary to protect the physical safety of a person or others from an immediate threat of physical injury or to protect against an immediate threat of severe property damage.

section.heading: ï¿½Mechanical restraintï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Mechanical restraintï¿½ means the use of devices, including, without limitation, mittens, straps, restraint chairs, handcuffs, belly chains and four-point restraints to limit a personï¿½s movement or hold a person immobile.

section.heading: ï¿½Person with a disabilityï¿½ defined.

content.p: Has a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more of the major life activities of the person; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has a record of such an impairment; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is regarded as having such an impairment.

section.heading: ï¿½Physical restraintï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Physical restraintï¿½ means the use of physical contact to limit a personï¿½s movement or hold a person immobile.

section.heading: ï¿½Verbal and mental abuseï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Verbal and mental abuseï¿½ means verbal intimidation or coercion of a person without a redeeming purpose.

section.heading: Use of aversive intervention on consumer prohibited.

content.p: A person employed by a facility or any other person shall not use any aversive intervention on a person with a disability who is a consumer.

section.heading: Use of physical, mechanical or chemical restraint on consumer by facility authorized in certain circumstances.

content.p: Accredited by a nationally recognized accreditation association or agency; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Certified for participation in the Medicaid or Medicare Program, ï¿½only to the extent that the accreditation or certification allows the use of such restraint.

section.heading: Use of physical, mechanical or chemical restraint on consumer by person employed by facility prohibited; exceptions.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided inNRS 433.5493, use physical restraint on a person with a disability who is a consumer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided inNRS 433.5496and433.5499, use mechanical restraint on a person with a disability who is a consumer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided inNRS 433.5503, use chemical restraint on a person with a disability who is a consumer.

section.heading: Use of physical restraint on consumer; requirements; exceptions; report as denial of rights.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, physical restraint may be used on a person with a disability who is a consumer only if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The physical restraint is used only for the period that is necessary to contain the behavior of the consumer so that the consumer is no longer an immediate threat of causing physical injury to himself or herself or others or causing severe property damage; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The use of force in the application of physical restraint does not exceed the force that is reasonable and necessary under the circumstances precipitating the use of physical restraint. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Physical restraint may be used on a person with a disability who is a consumer and the provisions of subsection 1 do not apply if the physical restraint is used to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Assist the consumer in completing a task or response if the consumer does not resist the application of physical restraint or if the consumerï¿½s resistance is minimal in intensity and duration; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Escort or carry a consumer to safety if the consumer is in danger in his or her present location; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Conduct medical examinations or treatments on the consumer that are necessary. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If physical restraint is used on a person with a disability who is a consumer in an emergency, the use of the procedure must be reported as a denial of rights pursuant toNRS 433.534or435.610, as applicable, regardless of whether the use of the procedure is authorized by statute. The report must be made not later than 1 working day after the procedure is used.

section.heading: Use of mechanical restraint on consumer other than consumer of forensic facility; requirements; exceptions; report as denial of rights.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsections 2 and 4, mechanical restraint may be used on a person with a disability who is a consumer only if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A medical order authorizing the use of mechanical restraint is obtained from the consumerï¿½s treating physician or advanced practice registered nurse before the application of the mechanical restraint or not later than 15 minutes after the application of the mechanical restraint; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The physician or advanced practice registered nurse who signed the order required pursuant to paragraph

or the attending physician or attending advanced practice registered nurse examines the consumer not later than 1 working day immediately after the application of the mechanical restraint; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The mechanical restraint is applied by a member of the staff of the facility who is trained and qualified to apply mechanical restraint; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The consumer is given the opportunity to move and exercise the parts of his or her body that are restrained at least 10 minutes per every 60 minutes of restraint; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A member of the staff of the facility lessens or discontinues the restraint every 15 minutes to determine whether the consumer will stop or control his or her inappropriate behavior without the use of the restraint; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The record of the consumer contains a notation that includes the time of day that the restraint was lessened or discontinued pursuant to paragraph
, the response of the consumer and the response of the member of the staff of the facility who applied the mechanical restraint; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A member of the staff of the facility continuously monitors the consumer during the time that mechanical restraint is used on the consumer; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The mechanical restraint is used only for the period that is necessary to contain the behavior of the consumer so that the consumer is no longer an immediate threat of causing physical injury to himself or herself or others or causing severe property damage. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Mechanical restraint may be used on a person with a disability who is a consumer and the provisions of subsection 1 do not apply if the mechanical restraint is used to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Treat the medical needs of a consumer; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Protect a consumer who is known to be at risk of injury to himself or herself because the consumer lacks coordination or suffers from frequent loss of consciousness; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Position a consumer who has physical disabilities in a manner prescribed in the consumerï¿½s plan of services. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If mechanical restraint is used on a person with a disability who is a consumer in an emergency, the use of the procedure must be reported as a denial of rights pursuant toNRS 433.534or435.610, as applicable, regardless of whether the use of the procedure is authorized by statute. The report must be made not later than 1 working day after the procedure is used. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of this section do not apply to a forensic facility, as that term is defined in subsection 5 ofNRS 433.5499.

section.heading: Use of mechanical restraint on consumer of forensic facility; requirements; exceptions; report as denial of rights.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, mechanical restraint may be used on a person with a disability who is a consumer of a forensic facility only if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The consumerï¿½s behavior presents an imminent threat of causing physical injury to himself or herself or to others or causing severe property damage and less restrictive measures have failed to modify the consumerï¿½s behavior; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The consumer is in the care of the facility but not on the premises of the facility and mechanical restraint is necessary to ensure security; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The consumer is in the process of being transported to another location and mechanical restraint is necessary to ensure security. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If mechanical restraint is used pursuant to subsection 1, the forensic facility shall ensure that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The mechanical restraint is applied by a member of the staff of the facility who is trained and qualified to apply mechanical restraint; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A member of the staff of the facility continuously monitors the consumer during the time that mechanical restraint is used on the consumer; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The record of the consumer contains a notation that indicates the time period during which the restraint was used and the circumstances warranting the restraint; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The mechanical restraint is used only for the period that is necessary. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Mechanical restraint may be used on a person with a disability who is a consumer of a forensic facility, and the provisions of subsections 1 and 2 do not apply if the mechanical restraint is used to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Treat the medical needs of a consumer; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Protect a consumer who is known to be at risk of injury to himself or herself because the consumer lacks coordination or suffers from frequent loss of consciousness; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Position a consumer who has physical disabilities in a manner prescribed in the consumerï¿½s plan of services. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If mechanical restraint is used in an emergency on a person with a disability who is a consumer of a forensic facility, the use of the procedure must be reported as a denial of rights pursuant toNRS 433.534or435.610, as applicable, regardless of whether the use of the procedure is authorized by statute. The report must be made not later than 1 working day after the procedure is used. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

As used in this section, ï¿½forensic facilityï¿½ means a secure facility of the Division for offenders and defendants with a mental disorder who are ordered to the facility pursuant tochapter 178of NRS.

section.heading: Use of chemical restraint on consumer; requirements; report as denial of rights.

content.p: Chemical restraint may only be used on a person with a disability who is a consumer if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The consumer has been deemed to be a person in a mental health crisis, as defined inNRS 433A.0175, and is receiving mental health services from a facility; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A medical order authorizing the use of chemical restraint is obtained from the consumerï¿½s attending physician, psychiatrist or advanced practice registered nurse; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The physician, psychiatrist or advanced practice registered nurse who signed the order required pursuant to paragraph
examines the consumer not later than 1 working day immediately after the administration of the chemical restraint; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The chemical restraint is administered by a person licensed to administer medication. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If chemical restraint is used on a person with a disability who is a consumer, the use of the procedure must be reported as a denial of rights pursuant toNRS 433.534or435.610, as applicable, regardless of whether the use of the procedure is authorized by statute. The report must be made not later than 1 working day after the procedure is used.

section.heading: Facility required to develop program of education in positive behavioral interventions and supports; facility required to train certain members of staff to use physical, mechanical and chemical restraint.

content.p: Each facility shall develop a program of education for the members of the staff of the facility to provide instruction in positive behavioral interventions and positive behavioral supports that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Includes positive methods to modify the environment of consumers to promote adaptive behavior and reduce the occurrence of inappropriate behavior; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Includes the use of the least intrusive methods to respond to and reinforce the behavior of consumers; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Offers a process for designing interventions based upon the consumer that are focused on promoting appropriate changes in behavior as well as enhancing the overall quality of life for the consumer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Each facility shall provide appropriate training for the members of the staff of the facility who are authorized to carry out and monitor physical restraint, mechanical restraint and chemical restraint to ensure that those members of the staff are competent and qualified to carry out the procedures in accordance withNRS 433.545to433.551, inclusive.

section.heading: Facility required to report violations to Division and to develop corrective plan; Division required to forward corrective plan to Director of Department; power of Department to withhold funding.

content.p: A facility where a violation of the provisions ofNRS 433.545to433.551, inclusive, occurs shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Not later than 24 hours after a violation occurs, or as soon thereafter as the violation is discovered, report the violation to the Division; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Develop, in cooperation with the Division, a corrective plan to ensure that within 30 calendar days after the violation occurred, appropriate action is taken by the facility to prevent future violations. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Division shall forward the plan to the Director of the Department. The Director or the Directorï¿½s designee shall review the plan to ensure that it complies with applicable federal law and the statutes and regulations of this state. The Director or the designee may require appropriate revision of the plan to ensure compliance. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the facility where the violation occurred does not meet the requirements of the plan to the satisfaction of the Director or the designee, the Department may withhold funding for the facility until the facility meets the requirements of the plan.
An employee of a public or private mental health facility or any other person, except a consumer, who: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has reason to believe that a consumer of the Division or of a private facility offering mental health services has been or is being abused or neglected and fails to report it; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Brings intoxicating beverages or a controlled substance into any division facility occupied by consumers unless specifically authorized to do so by the administrative officer or a staff physician of the facility; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is under the influence of liquor or a controlled substance while employed in contact with consumers, unless in accordance with a lawfully issued prescription; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Enters into any transaction with a consumer involving the transfer of money or property for personal use or gain at the expense of the consumer; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Contrives the escape, elopement or absence of a consumer, ï¿½is guilty of a misdemeanor, in addition to any other penalties provided by law. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In addition to any other penalties provided by law, an employee of a public or private mental health facility or any other person, except a consumer, who willfully abuses or neglects a consumer: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a first violation that does not result in substantial bodily harm to the consumer, is guilty of a gross misdemeanor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a first violation that results in substantial bodily harm to the consumer, is guilty of a category B felony. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

For a second or subsequent violation, is guilty of a category B felony. ï¿½A person convicted of a category B felony pursuant to this section shall be punished by imprisonment in the state prison for a minimum term of not less than 1 year and a maximum term of not more than 6 years, or by a fine of not more than $5,000, or by both fine and imprisonment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person who is convicted pursuant to this section is ineligible for 5 years for appointment to or employment in a position in the state service and, if the person is an officer or employee of the State, the person forfeits his or her office or position. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A conviction pursuant to this section is, when applicable, grounds for disciplinary action against the person so convicted and the facility where the violation occurred. The Division may recommend to the appropriate agency or board the suspension or revocation of the professional license, registration, certificate or permit of a person convicted pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the purposes of this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Abuseï¿½ means any willful and unjustified infliction of pain, injury or mental anguish upon a consumer, including, but not limited to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided inNRS 433.5486, a violation ofNRS 433.549; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The use of physical, chemical or mechanical restraints or the use of seclusion in violation of federal law. ï¿½Any act which meets the standard of practice for care and treatment does not constitute abuse. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Consumerï¿½ includes any person who seeks, on the personï¿½s own or othersï¿½ initiative, and can benefit from, care, treatment and training in a public or private institution or facility offering mental health services, or from treatment to competency in a public or private institution or facility offering mental health services. The term includes a consumer of the Division of Child and Family Services of the Department. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Neglectï¿½ means any omission to act which causes injury to a consumer or which places the consumer at risk of injury, including, but not limited to, the failure to follow: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An appropriate plan of treatment to which the consumer has consented; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The policies of the facility for the care and treatment of consumers. ï¿½Any omission to act which meets the standard of practice for care and treatment does not constitute neglect. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Standard of practiceï¿½ means the skill and care ordinarily exercised by prudent professional personnel engaged in health care.

section.heading: Unlawful sale or transfer of intoxicating beverage on grounds of division facility.

content.p: Any person who, on the grounds of a division facility, sells, barters, exchanges or in any manner disposes of any spirituous or malt liquor or beverage to any person lawfully confined in the division facility is guilty of a gross misdemeanor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not apply to any physician prescribing or furnishing liquor to the person when the liquor is prescribed or furnished for medicinal purposes only.

content.p: As used inNRS 433.622to433.641, inclusive, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined inNRS 433.623to433.629, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

content.p: ï¿½Peer recovery support servicesï¿½ means nonclinical supportive services that use lived experience in recovery from a substance use disorder or other behavioral health disorder to promote recovery in another person with a substance use disorder or other behavioral health disorder by advocating, mentoring, educating, offering hope and providing assistance in navigating systems.

content.p: ï¿½Peer recovery support specialistï¿½ means an adult who is authorized under the provisions ofNRS 433.631to provide peer recovery support services for compensation as a regular part of his or her job duties. The term does not include a peer recovery support specialist intern.

section.heading: ï¿½Peer recovery support specialist internï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Peer recovery support specialist internï¿½ means an adult who is authorized under the provisions ofNRS 433.631to provide peer recovery support services for compensation as a regular part of his or her job duties while the adult is acquiring the experience necessary for certification as a peer recovery support specialist.

section.heading: ï¿½Peer recovery support specialist supervisorï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Peer recovery support specialist supervisorï¿½ means an adult who is authorized under the provisions ofNRS 433.631to supervise the provision of peer recovery support services for compensation as a regular part of his or her job duties.

section.heading: Certificate required to provide or supervise provision of peer recovery support services; exception for interns; civil penalty. [Effective until the date on which the Nevada Certification Board, or its successor organization, ceases certifying peer recovery support specialists or peer recovery support specialist supervisors.]

content.p: Except as authorized by subsection 2, an adult shall not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Provide peer recovery support services for compensation as a regular part of his or her job duties or hold himself or herself out as authorized to provide peer recovery support services unless he or she holds a valid certificate as a peer recovery support specialist issued by the Nevada Certification Board or its successor organization. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Supervise the provision of peer recovery support services for compensation as a regular part of his or her job duties or hold himself or herself out as authorized to supervise the provision of peer recovery support services unless he or she holds a valid certificate as a peer recovery support specialist supervisor issued by the Nevada Certification Board or its successor organization. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the Nevada Certification Board or its successor organization establishes conditions governing the provision of peer recovery support services by a person who is not certified as a peer recovery support specialist while the person is acquiring the experience necessary for certification as a peer recovery support specialist, an adult who is not certified as a peer recovery support specialist may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

section.heading: Regulations; fees. [Effective on the date on which the Nevada Certification Board, or its successor organization, ceases certifying peer recovery support specialists or peer recovery support specialist supervisors.]

content.p: The Board shall adopt regulations governing the provision of peer recovery support services. The regulations must prescribe: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Requirements governing the supervision of peer recovery support specialists by peer recovery support specialist supervisors. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Procedures for the Division to investigate misconduct by a peer recovery support specialist or peer recovery support specialist supervisor and to impose disciplinary action for such misconduct. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The forms of disciplinary action that the Division may impose against a peer recovery support specialist or peer recovery support specialist supervisor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Board may, by regulation, prescribe a fee for: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The issuance of a certificate; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The renewal of a certificate. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any fee prescribed pursuant to subsection 2 must be calculated to produce the revenue estimated to cover the costs related to the issuance and renewal of certificates, but in no case may the fee for the issuance or renewal of a certificate exceed the actual cost to the Division of issuing or renewing the certificate, as applicable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Division shall include the statement required pursuant to subsection 1 in: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The application or any other forms that must be submitted for the issuance or renewal of the certificate; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

content.p: The Division shall support the implementation of a hotline for persons who are considering suicide or otherwise in a behavioral health crisis that may be accessed by dialing the digits 9-8-8 by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

of subsection 1 must be: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

content.p: Any support center established pursuant toNRS 433.704must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

section.heading: Creation; appointment, qualifications, terms and compensation of members.

content.p: The Advisory Committee for a Resilient Nevada is hereby created within the Department. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Attorney General shall appoint to the Advisory Committee: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
One member who possesses knowledge, skills and experience in the surveillance of overdoses; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Resides in a county other than Clark or Washoe County; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

of subsection 1 ofNRS 433.734, including, without limitation, the establishment of priorities pursuant to paragraph
of subsection 1 ofNRS 433.736; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

section.heading: Return of prescription drug to dispensing pharmacy for reissuance or transfer of drug; reissuance or transfer of drug by dispensing pharmacy; regulations.

content.p: A public or private mental health facility may return a prescription drug that is dispensed to a patient of the facility, but will not be used by that patient, to the dispensing pharmacy for the purpose of reissuing the drug to fill other prescriptions for patients in that facility or for the purpose of transferring the drug to a nonprofit pharmacy designated by the State Board of Pharmacy pursuant toNRS 639.2676if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The drug is not a controlled substance; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The drug is dispensed in a unit dose, in individually sealed doses or in a bottle that is sealed by the manufacturer of the drug; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The usefulness of the drug has not expired; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The packaging or bottle contains the expiration date of the usefulness of the drug; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The name of the patient for whom the drug was originally prescribed, the prescription number and any other identifying marks are obliterated from the packaging or bottle before the return of the drug. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A dispensing pharmacy to which a drug is returned pursuant to this section may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Reissue the drug to fill other prescriptions for patients in the same facility if the registered pharmacist of the pharmacy determines that the drug is suitable for that purpose in accordance with standards adopted by the State Board of Pharmacy pursuant to subsection 5; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Transfer the drug to a nonprofit pharmacy designated by the State Board of Pharmacy pursuant toNRS 639.2676. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
No drug that is returned to a dispensing pharmacy pursuant to this section may be used to fill other prescriptions more than one time. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A mental health facility shall adopt written procedures for returning drugs to a dispensing pharmacy pursuant to this section. The procedures must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Provide appropriate safeguards for ensuring that the drugs are not compromised or illegally diverted during their return. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Require the maintenance and retention of such records relating to the return of such drugs as are required by the State Board of Pharmacy. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Be approved by the State Board of Pharmacy. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The State Board of Pharmacy shall adopt such regulations as are necessary to carry out the provisions of this section, including, without limitation, requirements for: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Returning and reissuing such drugs pursuant to the provisions of this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Transferring drugs to a nonprofit pharmacy pursuant to the provisions of this section andNRS 639.2676. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Maintaining records relating to the return and the use of such drugs to fill other prescriptions.

section.heading: Required considerations before placing person with mental illness or person with developmental disability.

content.p: Any person or entity, including, without limitation, the Division, that determines the placement of a person with a mental illness or a person with a developmental disability in a mental health facility, medical facility, facility for the dependent or any other placement shall, when making such a determination, consider whether the mental health facility, medical facility, facility for the dependent or other placement is capable of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
